text: we've had I think nine or ten press
conferences in this room since Saturday
when the plane first went missing we
haven't really frankly heard a great
deal more from the Malaysian officials
than they were able to tell us in that
first morning and they expressed their
own frustration they say about being as
baffled as we are about the lack of any
information even on where the plane was
at the point it disappeared there seems
to be quite a lot of conflicting
information about whether it's simply
vanished at the point it was
transferring from Malaysian to
Vietnamese airspace or whether it turned
back as the Malaysian military radar
records suggest the fact that they're
actually searching on the west coast of
Malaysia and the Straits of Malacca
that's a good hours flight easily from
where they think the plane went down
tells you how confused they are of
course it spreads the search area out to
a much larger space we've got for quite
sophisticated reconnaissance planes the
United States Australia and New Zealand
now in operation the Americans say that
their equipment can pick out the
smallest amounts of debris on the sea
there they've been scanning it they say
up to now they've only seen bits of
flotsam bits of wood and rubbish but it
tells you how the capabilities that are
there now and how extraordinary it is
that if a plane this size did go down
but there is no sign of any debris
whatsoever we've now got more than 40
ships that have been scouring the sea
for more than 48 hours
